lessons.title: Types of Relations
lessons.content:
# Relations

## Types
- **Reflexive**: (a,a) for all a
- **Symmetric**: If (a,b) then (b,a)
- **Transitive**: If (a,b) and (b,c) then (a,c)
- **Equivalence**: Reflexive, symmetric, and transitive

lessons.title: Types of Functions
lessons.content:
# Functions

## Types
- **Injective** (One-to-one)
- **Surjective** (Onto)
- **Bijective** (Both injective and surjective)
- **Inverse functions**

questions.question: Reflexive relation has:
questions.explanation: Reflexive relation contains (a,a) for all elements a.

questions.question: Equivalence relation must be:
questions.explanation: Equivalence relation must be reflexive, symmetric, and transitive.

questions.question: Injective function is:
questions.explanation: Injective (one-to-one) function maps distinct inputs to distinct outputs.

questions.question: Surjective function means:
options: Every element in codomain is mapped
questions.explanation: Surjective (onto) function maps to every element in the codomain.

questions.question: Bijective function is:
questions.explanation: Bijective function is both one-to-one and onto.

questions.question: For inverse to exist, function must be:
questions.explanation: A function must be bijective to have an inverse.

questions.question: Transitive relation: if (a,b) and (b,c) then:
questions.explanation: Transitive relation implies if (a,b) and (b,c) then (a,c).

questions.question: Identity function f(x) = x is:
questions.explanation: Identity function is bijective (both one-to-one and onto).

questions.question: Composition of functions (f∘g)(x) means:
questions.explanation: (f∘g)(x) means f(g(x)) - apply g first, then f.
